title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: CytoProfile depends mixOmics, must installed Bioconductor installing CytoProfile:
code: if (!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE)) {   install.packages("BiocManager") } BiocManager::install("mixOmics")

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
code: # From CRAN (stable release) install.packages("CytoProfile")  # From GitHub (development version) # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("saraswatsh/CytoProfile", ref = "devel")

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: CytoProfile imports necessary packages internally, need call library() dependencies (e.g., ggplot2, dplyr, mixOmics). exception vignette dplyr, used explicitly data subsetting examples re-exported CytoProfile.
code: library(CytoProfile) library(dplyr)   # used only for filter() in the examples below

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: CytoProfile functions expect data frame (coercible matrix) : Cytokine columns numeric (concentrations transformed values). Grouping columns (e.g., disease group, treatment) character factor. strict naming requirements, column names must unique. functions internally call make.names() sanitize names special characters (e.g., CCL-20/MIP-3A becomes CCL.20.MIP.3A). Missing values (NA) handled internally functions, rows -missing cytokine values removed prior analysis. CytoProfile ships five example datasets (ExampleData1 ExampleData5). Throughout vignette use ExampleData1, contains 297 observations 25 cytokines along Group, Treatment, Time columns. Recommended sample size: Functions perform best least 10 samples per group. Machine learning functions (Random Forest, XGBoost) require larger sample sizes (≥\ge 20 per group) produce reliable cross-validated performance estimates.
code: data("ExampleData1") data_df <- ExampleData1  # Inspect structure dim(data_df) #> [1] 297  28 names(data_df)[1:6] #> [1] "Group"     "Treatment" "Time"      "IL-17F"    "GM-CSF"    "IFN-G" head(data_df[, 1:5]) #>   Group Treatment Time IL-17F GM-CSF #> 1   T2D  CD3/CD28   20   3.31   7.16 #> 2   T2D  CD3/CD28   20   0.38   0.87 #> 3   T2D  CD3/CD28   20   1.25   2.47 #> 4   T2D  CD3/CD28   20   2.24   3.52 #> 5   T2D  CD3/CD28   20   0.25   1.58 #> 6   T2D  CD3/CD28   20   0.96   1.87 table(data_df$Group) #>  #>     ND PreT2D    T2D  #>     99     99     99 table(data_df$Treatment) #>  #>     CD3/CD28          LPS Unstimulated  #>           99           99           99

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Purpose: Generate boxplots numeric variable, optionally grouped one categorical variables. Key data requirements: - least one numeric column required. - group_by specified, columns must character factor. Key parameters: use scale: - "log2" "log10": cytokine concentrations span several orders magnitude show strong right-skew (common raw immunoassay data). - "zscore": comparing distributions standardized scale across cytokines different concentration ranges. - "none": data already transformed. Interpreting output: - boxplot shows median (horizontal line), interquartile range (box), 1.5x IQR whiskers, individual data points (jittered). - Overlapping distributions groups suggest strong group effect cytokine. - Outliers far beyond whiskers warrant attention - consider whether represent biological extremes measurement artefacts.   Note: cyt_bp() invisibly returns named list ggplot objects, can retrieve modify individual plot: plots <- cyt_bp(...); plots[["IL-10"]] + ggplot2::ggtitle("Custom title").
code: # Ungrouped boxplots with log2 transformation # All numeric columns are plotted; up to bin_size = 25 per page cyt_bp(data_df[, -c(1:3)], output_file = NULL, scale = "log2") # Grouped boxplots: one plot per cytokine, colored by Group # Only passing Group and two cytokines for a concise display cyt_bp(   data_df[, c("Group", "IL-10", "CCL-20/MIP-3A")],   group_by = "Group",   scale = "zscore" )

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Purpose: Similar cyt_bp() shows full data distribution shape using kernel density estimation, making especially informative bimodal asymmetric cytokine distributions. Key parameters (cyt_bp(), plus): Interpreting output: - wide violin belly indicates many observations value. - Bimodal violins (two wide regions) suggest subpopulations within group - worth investigating stratification. - Setting boxplot_overlay = TRUE combines density estimation quartile summaries one panel.
code: # Ungrouped violin plots with z-score scaling cyt_violin(data_df[, -c(1:3)], output_file = NULL, scale = "zscore") # Grouped violin plots with boxplot overlay and log2 scaling cyt_violin(   data_df[, c("Group", "IL-10", "CCL-20/MIP-3A")],   group_by = "Group",   boxplot_overlay = TRUE,   scale = "log2" )

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Purpose: Assess whether cytokine distributions symmetric (skewness ≈\approx 0) whether tails heavier normal distribution (kurtosis > 0). important deciding whether log transformation appropriate statistical testing. Key data requirements: - Numeric measurement columns (exclude grouping columns via group_cols). - values positive log2 transformation applied downstream, since cyt_skku() uses log2 internally comparison. Key parameters: Interpreting output: - Two histograms produced: one skewness, one kurtosis, comparing raw data (red) log2-transformed data (blue). - Skewness: Values far 0 indicate asymmetry. Positive skewness (right tail) common raw cytokine data. log2 transformation, distributions closer 0 indicate better symmetry. - Kurtosis: Positive excess kurtosis indicates heavier--normal tails (outliers expected). log2 transformation, kurtosis values closer 0 suggest transformation improved normality. - log2 transformation substantially reduces skewness kurtosis compared raw values, recommended pre-processing step.
code: # Overall distributional assessment (no grouping) cyt_skku(data_df[, -c(1:3)], output_file = NULL, group_cols = NULL) # Grouped assessment by "Group" cyt_skku(data_df[, -c(2:3)], output_file = NULL, group_cols = c("Group"))

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Purpose: Visualize central tendency spread cytokine across groups, optional statistical annotations (p-values effect sizes) comparing group first (baseline) group. Key data requirements: - least one numeric column one grouping column. - first factor level group_col used baseline comparisons. Key parameters: Interpreting output: - facet panel corresponds one cytokine. Bars show central tendency; error bars show spread. - P-value labels bars indicate statistical significance versus baseline group. Values ≤\le 0.05 conventionally significant. - Effect size labels indicate practical magnitude difference: larger absolute values denote greater differences. t-test comparisons, Cohen’s d; Wilcoxon, rank-biserial correlation. - class_symbol = TRUE renders significance stars (* *****) effect size arrows (> >>>>>), following conventions used accompanying publication.   Tip: Use p_adjust_method = "BH" analysing large cytokine panel control false discovery rate across multiple comparisons.
code: # Basic error bar plot: default mean +/- SE df_err <- ExampleData1[, c("Group", "CCL-20/MIP-3A", "IL-10")] cyt_errbp(   df_err,   group_col = "Group",   x_lab = "Group",   y_lab = "Concentration" ) # Mean +/- SD with log2 transformation, symbols, and t-test cyt_errbp(   df_err,   group_col = "Group",   stat = "mean",   error = "sd",   scale = "log2",   class_symbol = TRUE,   method = "ttest",   x_lab = "Group",   y_lab = "Concentration (log2)" )

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Purpose: Perform pairwise statistical tests exactly two groups numeric cytokine column. categorical predictor exactly two levels, either Student’s t-test Wilcoxon rank-sum test applied numeric outcome. Key data requirements: - least one factor/character column exactly two levels. - least one numeric column. - groups must ≥\ge 2 observations non-zero variance. Automatic test selection (method = "auto"): method = "auto", Shapiro-Wilk normality test applied pooled values cytokine within comparison. groups pass normality (p > 0.05), t-test used; otherwise, Wilcoxon rank-sum (Mann-Whitney U) test used. selection done independently cytokine. prefer consistent approach, set method = "ttest" method = "wilcox" explicitly. Key parameters: Interpreting output: - format_output = TRUE, data frame returned columns: Outcome (cytokine), Categorical (grouping variable), Comparison (group vs group B), Test (method used), Estimate, Statistic, P_value. - P-values < 0.05 indicate statistically significant difference groups cytokine. - testing many cytokines simultaneously, use p_adjust_method = "BH" control false discovery rate; adjusted column P_adj appended.
code: data_uni <- ExampleData1[, -c(3)] data_uni <- dplyr::filter(data_uni, Group != "ND", Treatment != "Unstimulated")  # Tidy output with log2 transformation and automatic test selection cyt_univariate(   data_uni[, c("Group", "Treatment", "IL-10", "CCL-20/MIP-3A")],   scale    = "log2",   method   = "auto",   format_output = TRUE,   p_adjust_method = "BH" ) #>         Outcome Categorical      Comparison #> 1         IL.10       Group   PreT2D vs T2D #> 2 CCL.20.MIP.3A       Group   PreT2D vs T2D #> 3         IL.10   Treatment CD3/CD28 vs LPS #> 4 CCL.20.MIP.3A   Treatment CD3/CD28 vs LPS #>                                                Test Estimate Statistic P_value #> 1 Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction   -0.956    1625.0   0.012 #> 2 Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction   -1.575    1050.5   0.000 #> 3 Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction    1.690    3091.0   0.000 #> 4 Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction    0.488    2509.5   0.132 #>   P_adj #> 1 0.016 #> 2 0.000 #> 3 0.000 #> 4 0.132

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Purpose: Extend univariate testing categorical predictors two levels using either ANOVA (parametric) Kruskal-Wallis (non-parametric) global tests, followed pairwise post-hoc comparisons. Key data requirements: - least one factor/character column two levels. - least one numeric column. - ANOVA restricted predictors ≤\le 10 levels. Key parameters: Interpreting output: - format_output = TRUE, data frame columns Outcome, Categorical, Comparison, P_adj returned. - row represents one pairwise comparison one cytokine. P_adj values < 0.05 indicate significant pairwise differences multiple testing correction. - Use method = "kruskal" cytokine data non-normal sample sizes small.
code: # Kruskal-Wallis with pairwise Wilcoxon for multi-group comparison cyt_univariate_multi(   ExampleData1[, c("Group", "IL-10", "CCL-20/MIP-3A")],   method = "kruskal",   format_output = TRUE ) #>         Outcome Categorical Comparison  P_adj #> 1         IL.10       Group  PreT2D-ND 0.2995 #> 2         IL.10       Group     T2D-ND 0.3181 #> 3         IL.10       Group T2D-PreT2D 0.0849 #> 4 CCL.20.MIP.3A       Group  PreT2D-ND 0.0518 #> 5 CCL.20.MIP.3A       Group     T2D-ND 0.0332 #> 6 CCL.20.MIP.3A       Group T2D-PreT2D 0.0001

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Purpose: Visualize fold change versus statistical significance cytokines two groups simultaneously, highlighting cytokines biologically meaningful (large fold change) statistically significant. Key data requirements: - One grouping column multiple numeric columns. - conditions specified must exist levels group_col. Key parameters: Interpreting output: - x-axis: log2 fold change (cond2 / cond1). Positive values indicate higher expression cond2; negative values cond1. - y-axis: -log10(p-value). Higher values = significant. - Dashed lines: Vertical lines mark +/-log2 fold change threshold; horizontal line marks -log10 p-value threshold. - Red points: Cytokines exceeding thresholds - candidates likely biologically relevant two conditions. - Labels: top_labels cytokines significant p-values labelled.
code: data_volc <- ExampleData1[, -c(2:3)]  volc_plots <- cyt_volc(   data_volc,   group_col = "Group",   cond1 = "T2D",   cond2 = "ND",   fold_change_thresh = 2.0,   p_value_thresh = 0.05,   top_labels = 15,   method = "ttest" )  # The function returns a named list of ggplot objects; print the comparison volc_plots[["T2D vs ND"]]

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Purpose: Visualize expression matrix cytokines across samples, optional annotation hierarchical clustering reveal sample groupings cytokine co-expression patterns. Key data requirements: - data frame containing numeric cytokine columns. Non-numeric columns ignored. - annotation column (used) must length equal number rows numeric matrix. Key parameters: Interpreting output: - color scale represents cytokine expression transformation: blue = low, white = mid, red = high. - Row dendrogram (left) clusters samples cytokine expression profiles. Samples cluster together share similar cytokine signatures. - Column dendrogram (top) clusters cytokines co-expression. Cytokines close together column dendrogram correlated across samples. - annotation sidebar (provided) color-codes samples group, making easy see whether cluster structure aligns biological groupings. - Hiding row names (show_row_names = FALSE) recommended many samples, individual sample labels become unreadable clutter plot.
code: cyt_heatmap(   data = data_df[, -c(2:3)],   scale = "log2",   annotation_col = "Group",   annotation_side = "auto",   show_row_names = FALSE,   title = NULL )

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Purpose: Simultaneously visualize effect size (SSMD - Strictly Standardized Mean Difference) fold change cytokines two groups. dual-flashlight plot particularly valuable identifying cytokines large effect size substantial fold change, strong candidates investigation biomarkers. SSMD instead p-values? Traditional p-values conflate effect size sample size: large study can yield significant p-values biologically trivial differences. SSMD quantifies effect size independently sample size, making suitable prioritizing cytokines panels varying sizes. Key data requirements: - data frame numeric cytokine columns one grouping column. - group1 group2 must levels present group_var. Key parameters: Interpreting output: - x-axis: Average log2 fold change. Positive = higher group1. - y-axis: SSMD. |SSMD| ≥\ge 1 = strong effect; |SSMD| ≥\ge 0.5 = moderate. - Point color: Effect strength category (strong = red, moderate = orange, weak = blue). - Point shape: Triangles indicate cytokines exceed SSMD log2FC thresholds simultaneously - compelling candidates. - Dashed lines: Mark defined thresholds. - Cytokines upper-right lower-left quadrants beyond dashed lines elevated group1 group2 respectively, strong effect substantial fold change.
code: data_dfp <- ExampleData1[, -c(2:3)]  dfp <- cyt_dualflashplot(   data_dfp,   group_var    = "Group",   group1       = "T2D",   group2       = "ND",   ssmd_thresh  = 0.2,   log2fc_thresh = 1,   top_labels   = 10,   verbose      = FALSE ) dfp # Inspect the underlying statistics head(dfp$data[order(abs(dfp$data$ssmd), decreasing = TRUE), ], 10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 11 #>    cytokine        mean_ND mean_PreT2D   mean_T2D variance_ND variance_PreT2D #>    <chr>             <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl>       <dbl>           <dbl> #>  1 IL.6          4620.       5197.      8925.         2.86e+7         5.72e+7 #>  2 IL.27            0.0662      0.0834     0.106      6.18e-3         5.66e-3 #>  3 IL.12.P70       13.0        39.1       78.9        4.15e+2         2.56e+4 #>  4 IL.23            0.147       0.243      0.269      3.13e-2         9.37e-2 #>  5 CCL.20.MIP.3A  634.        404.       887.         6.72e+5         2.74e+5 #>  6 IL.2          9227.      10718.     16129.         2.60e+8         4.10e+8 #>  7 IL.17F           1.63        2.35       3.11       1.56e+1         3.37e+1 #>  8 IL.10          979.        836.      1366.         1.99e+6         1.19e+6 #>  9 IL.28A           0.0537      0.0710     0.0666     2.45e-3         5.10e-3 #> 10 IL.17A         352.        653.       615.         9.40e+5         2.88e+6 #> # ℹ 5 more variables: variance_T2D <dbl>, ssmd <dbl>, log2FC <dbl>, #> #   Effect <fct>, Significant <lgl>

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Purpose: Reduce dimensionality cytokine data visualize sample-level variation across groups. PCA identifies axes (principal components) greatest variance data without using group labels, making unsupervised method suitable initial exploration. Key data requirements: - least one grouping column multiple numeric cytokine columns. - sufficient number observations relative number cytokines recommended (least n > p, ideally n > 3p). Key parameters: Interpreting output: - Individuals plot: point one sample. Points close together similar cytokine profiles. Clear separation colored groups suggests discriminating cytokine signature exists. - Scree plot: Shows percentage variance explained component (individual, blue) cumulatively (dashed green). Choose number components capture ≥\ge 70-80% variance. - Loadings plot: Shows cytokines contribute component. Long bars = large contribution. sign indicates direction (positive loading = higher values push samples positive direction along component). - Biplot: Overlays sample scores cytokine loadings. Cytokine arrows pointing toward group cluster indicate cytokines elevated group. - Correlation circle: Cytokines near edge circle well represented selected two components. Cytokines close together positively correlated; opposite negatively correlated.
code: data_pca <- ExampleData1[, -c(3, 23)] data_pca <- dplyr::filter(data_pca, Group != "ND" & Treatment != "Unstimulated")  pca_results <- cyt_pca(   data_pca,   output_file  = NULL,   colors       = c("black", "red2"),   scale        = "log2",   comp_num     = 2,   pch_values   = c(16, 4),   group_col    = "Group",   ellipse      = TRUE ) pca_results$overall_indiv_plot pca_results$scree_plot pca_results$loadings$Comp1() pca_results$correlation_circle()

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Purpose: supervised multivariate method finds linear combinations cytokines maximally discriminate groups, simultaneously selecting discriminating cytokines (sparsity). Unlike PCA, sPLS-DA uses group labels guide component construction. Key data requirements: - least two groups group_col. - Multiple numeric cytokine columns. - reliable cross-validation, ≥\ge 10 samples per group recommended. Key parameters: Interpreting output: - Classification plot (individuals plot): Labelled accuracy (% training samples correctly classified). Clear separation indicates model successfully identified discriminating cytokine signature. - Loadings plot: Shows cytokines load strongly component group elevated (color bar). contrib = "max" setting colors bar group highest mean cytokine. - VIP scores plot: Variable Importance Projection scores component. Cytokines VIP > 1 considered important discriminators used fit refined model. - VIP > 1 classification plot: second model fitted using VIP > 1 cytokines. Comparing accuracy full VIP-filtered model shows whether signature can simplified. - Cross-validation error plot (cv_opt set): Error rate across components. optimal number components error rate plateaus reaches minimum.
code: data_spls <- ExampleData1[, -c(3)] data_spls <- dplyr::filter(data_spls, Group != "ND" & Treatment == "CD3/CD28")  spls_results <- cyt_splsda(   data_spls,   output_file  = NULL,   colors       = c("black", "purple"),   scale        = "log2",   ellipse      = TRUE,   var_num      = 25,   cv_opt       = "loocv",   comp_num     = 2,   pch_values   = c(16, 4),   group_col    = "Group",   group_col2   = "Treatment",   roc          = FALSE,   verbose      = FALSE ) spls_results$overall_indiv_plot spls_results$vip_indiv_plot spls_results$loadings$Comp1() spls_results$vip_scores$Comp1()

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Purpose: extension sPLS-DA datasets collected across multiple batches studies. MINT (Multivariate INTegration) models global biological signal accounting batch-specific variation, making appropriate data combined directly due technical differences collection sites time points. Key data requirements: - cyt_splsda(), plus batch_col column identifying batch/study sample belongs . - least two batches required; batch contain samples groups possible. Key parameters: cyt_splsda(), plus: Interpreting output: - Identical cyt_splsda() outputs, addition partial plots (one per batch), show well global model fits within individual batch. - global individuals plot show separation groups even batch effects present - groups overlap global plot separate partial plots, batch effect dominating signal.
code: data_mint <- ExampleData5[, -c(2, 4)] data_mint <- dplyr::filter(data_mint, Group != "ND")  mint_results <- cyt_mint_splsda(   data_mint,   group_col  = "Group",   batch_col  = "Batch",   colors     = c("black", "purple"),   ellipse    = TRUE,   var_num    = 25,   comp_num   = 2,   scale      = "log2",   verbose    = FALSE ) mint_results$global_indiv_plot mint_results$partial_indiv_plot mint_results$global_loadings_plots$Comp1()

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Recommended sample size: reliable performance estimates, machine learning methods require larger datasets. minimum 20 samples per class recommended; cross-validation estimates become stable ≥\ge 50 samples per class.

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Purpose: Train gradient-boosted tree classifier cytokine data multi-class binary group classification. XGBoost well suited high-dimensional cytokine panels provides feature importance -product. Key data requirements: - One grouping column (outcome) multiple numeric cytokine predictors. - Grouping column encoded numeric labels internally (0-indexed). Key parameters: Note Ckmeans.1d.dp: xgb.ggplot.importance() function optionally uses Ckmeans.1d.dp package clustered importance plot. package installed, cyt_xgb() automatically fall back standard bar chart. Install install.packages("Ckmeans.1d.dp") enhanced plot. Interpreting output: - Confusion matrix: Rows = actual classes; columns = predicted classes. diagonal shows correct classifications. -diagonal values misclassifications. - Feature importance plot: Shows top top_n_features cytokines ranked Gain (improvement loss function attributable feature). Cytokines higher Gain important classification. - Cross-validation accuracy (cv = TRUE): Provides estimate --sample performance less susceptible overfitting training accuracy alone. - ROC curve (binary ): Area Curve (AUC) summarizes classifier performance across thresholds. AUC = 1 perfect; AUC = 0.5 better chance.
code: data_ml <- data.frame(ExampleData1[, 1:3], log2(ExampleData1[, -c(1:3)])) data_ml <- data_ml[, -c(2:3)] data_ml <- dplyr::filter(data_ml, Group != "ND")  cyt_xgb(   data          = data_ml,   group_col     = "Group",   nrounds       = 250,   max_depth     = 4,   learning_rate = 0.05,   nfold         = 5,   cv            = FALSE,   objective     = "multi:softprob",   eval_metric   = "mlogloss",   top_n_features = 10,   verbose       = 0,   plot_roc      = FALSE,   print_results = FALSE,   seed          = 123 )

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: Purpose: Train random forest ensemble classifier cytokine data. Random forests robust outliers correlated predictors, naturally provide variable importance mean decrease Gini impurity. Key parameters: Interpreting output: - Variable importance plot: Cytokines ordered Mean Decrease Gini. Higher values indicate greater discrimination ability. complements sPLS-DA loadings non-linear importance measure. - Cross-validation error curve (run_rfcv = TRUE): Error rate versus number variables. elbow curve (error stabilizes) suggests minimum number cytokines needed good classification. useful building parsimonious panels. - ROC curve (binary ): interpretation cyt_xgb().
code: cyt_rf(   data       = data_ml,   group_col  = "Group",   ntree      = 500,   mtry       = 4,   k_folds    = 5,   run_rfcv   = TRUE,   plot_roc   = FALSE,   verbose    = FALSE,   seed       = 123 )

text: functions return ggplot objects invisibly, enabling customization:
code: p <- cyt_bp(data_df[, -c(1:3)], scale = "log2") # Add a custom title to the first page p[["page1"]] + ggplot2::ggtitle("My Custom Title") +   ggplot2::theme(plot.title = ggplot2::element_text(size = 16))

title: Getting Started with CytoProfile
text: following workflow recommended typical cytokine profiling study: Load inspect data - check dimensions, column types, missingness. Assess distributions (cyt_skku()) - determine whether log2 transformation warranted. Exploratory visualization (cyt_bp() cyt_violin(), cyt_errbp()) - identify obvious group differences data quality issues. Univariate testing (cyt_univariate(), cyt_univariate_multi()) - FDR correction panels > 10 cytokines. Multivariate exploration (cyt_pca()) - visualize global structure assess whether groups separate. Supervised discrimination (cyt_splsda()) - identify minimal cytokine signature discriminates groups; validate cross-validation. Visualization key findings (cyt_volc(), cyt_dualflashplot(), cyt_heatmap()) - summarize significant high-effect cytokines reporting. Machine learning validation (cyt_rf(), cyt_xgb()) - obtain independent importance rankings classification performance estimates.

NULL (default) numeric columns transformed. scale character string specifying transformation apply.  Possible values "none", "log2", "log10", "zscore", "custom".  set "custom" function specified custom_fn applied columns. custom_fn function takes numeric vector returns transformed numeric vector.  used scale = "custom".

what: ANOVA Analysis on Continuous Variables.  — cyt_anova
title: ANOVA Analysis on Continuous Variables.  — cyt_anova
text: function performs analysis variance (ANOVA) continuous variable every categorical predictor input data. Character columns automatically converted factors; factor columns used predictors numeric columns used continuous outcomes. valid predictor (.e., one level 10 levels), Tukey's Honest Significant Difference (HSD) test conducted adjusted p-values pairwise comparisons extracted.

title: ANOVA Analysis on Continuous Variables.  — cyt_anova

title: ANOVA Analysis on Continuous Variables.  — cyt_anova
text: data data frame matrix containing categorical continuous variables. Character columns converted factors used predictors, numeric columns used continuous outcomes. format_output Logical. TRUE, returns results tidy data frame instead list. Default FALSE.

title: ANOVA Analysis on Continuous Variables.  — cyt_anova
text: format_output FALSE (default), list adjusted p-values Tukey's HSD tests combination continuous outcome categorical predictor. List elements named format "Outcome_Categorical". format_output TRUE, data frame tidy format.

title: Dual-flashlight Plot — cyt_dualflashplot
text: function reshapes input data computes summary statistics (mean variance) variable grouped specified factor column. calculates SSMD (Strictly Standardized Mean Difference) log2 fold change two groups (group1 group2) categorizes effect strength "Strong Effect", "Moderate Effect", "Weak Effect". dual flash plot generated using ggplot2 x-axis represents average log2 fold change y-axis represents SSMD. Additionally, function prints computed statistics console. ggplot object returned modification.

title: Dual-flashlight Plot — cyt_dualflashplot
code: cyt_dualflashplot(   data,   group_var,   group1,   group2,   ssmd_thresh = 1,   log2fc_thresh = 1,   top_labels = 15,   category_labels = c(Strong = "Strong Effect", Moderate = "Moderate Effect", Weak =     "Weak Effect"),   colors = c(`Strong Effect` = "red", `Moderate Effect` = "orange", `Weak Effect` =     "blue"),   shapes = c(`FALSE` = 16, `TRUE` = 17),   verbose = FALSE )

title: Dual-flashlight Plot — cyt_dualflashplot
text: data data frame containing least one numeric column grouping column. group_var Character.  Name grouping column. group1 Character strings identifying two levels group_var compare. group2 Character strings identifying two levels group_var compare. ssmd_thresh Numeric.  Absolute SSMD threshold highlighting observations significant.  Default 1. log2fc_thresh Numeric.  Absolute log2 fold change threshold significance.  Default 1. top_labels Integer.  Number variables largest absolute SSMD label plot.  Default 15. category_labels Optional named character vector length three providing alternative labels SSMD effect categories.  Names must include "Strong", "Moderate" "Weak".  Defaults c(Strong = "Strong Effect", Moderate = "Moderate Effect", Weak = "Weak Effect"). colors Optional named character vector mapping effect categories colors.  Names must match category_labels.  Defaults red strong, orange moderate blue weak. shapes Optional named numeric vector length two giving plotting characters non‑significant significant points.  Defaults c(FALSE= 16,TRUE = 17) (solid triangular symbols). verbose Logical.  TRUE, prints computed summary statistics.  Default FALSE.

title: Error-bar Plot — cyt_errbp
text: function generates error-bar plot visually compare different groups designated baseline group. displays central tendency (mean median) bar overlays error bars represent data's spread (e.g., standard deviation, MAD, standard error). plot can also include p-value effect size labels (based SSMD), presented either symbols numeric values, highlight significant differences magnitude effects. output filename provided plot saved disk; otherwise ggplot object returned drawn current graphics device.

title: Error-bar Plot — cyt_errbp
text: data data frame containing least one numeric column grouping column. group_col Character string naming column defines groups.  column coerced factor. p_lab Logical.  TRUE (default) p‑value labels displayed group comparisons. es_lab Logical.  TRUE (default) effect‑size labels displayed. class_symbol Logical.  TRUE, p‑value effect‑size labels encoded using symbols (e.g., *, >>>). FALSE(default), numeric values shown instead. x_lab Character string x-axis label.  empty default label generated. y_lab Character string y-axis label.  empty default label generated. title Character string plot title.  empty default title generated. stat Character.  Central tendency statistic use.  Choices "mean" "median"; default "mean".  Added support non‑mean summaries. error Character.  Error measure visualized around statistic.  Options "se" (standard error; default), "sd" (standard deviation), "mad" (median absolute deviation) "ci" (approximate 95 % confidence interval). scale Character controlling data transformation analysis.  Accepts "none" (default), "log2", "log10", "zscore" "custom". custom_fn user‑supplied function applied numeric columns scale = "custom". method Character controlling statistical test used pairwise comparisons.  Options "auto" (default; choose t‑test Wilcoxon based normality test), "ttest" "wilcox". p_adjust_method Character.  non‑NULL, specifies method used p.adjust() correct p‑values across comparisons (e.g., "BH" Benjamini–Hochberg).  NULL (default) adjustment performed. output_file Optional file path.  provided, plot saved using ggsave(); otherwise plot returned automatically printed. label_size Numeric.  Font size p‑value effect‑size labels.  Default 4.

what: Analyze data with Sparse Partial Least Squares Discriminant Analysis (sPLS-DA). — cyt_splsda
title: Analyze data with Sparse Partial Least Squares Discriminant Analysis (sPLS-DA). — cyt_splsda
text: function conducts Sparse Partial Least Squares Discriminant Analysis (sPLS-DA) provided data. uses specified group_col (optionally group_col2) define class labels assuming remaining columns contain continuous variables. function supports transformations via scale parameter generates series plots, including classification plots, scree plots, loadings plots, VIP score plots. Optionally, ROC curves produced roc TRUE. Additionally, cross-validation supported via LOOCV Mfold methods. group_col group_col2 provided differ, function analyzes treatment level separately.

title: Analyze data with Sparse Partial Least Squares Discriminant Analysis (sPLS-DA). — cyt_splsda
code: cyt_splsda(   data,   group_col = NULL,   group_col2 = NULL,   multilevel_col = NULL,   batch_col = NULL,   ind_names = FALSE,   colors = NULL,   output_file = NULL,   ellipse = FALSE,   bg = FALSE,   conf_mat = FALSE,   var_num,   cv_opt = NULL,   fold_num = 5,   scale = c("none", "log2", "log10", "zscore", "custom"),   custom_fn = NULL,   tune = FALSE,   tune_folds = 5,   comp_num = 2,   pch_values,   style = NULL,   roc = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE,   seed = 123 )

title: Analyze data with Sparse Partial Least Squares Discriminant Analysis (sPLS-DA). — cyt_splsda
text: data matrix data frame containing variables. Columns specified group_col group_col2 assumed continuous variables analysis. group_col string specifying column name contains first group information. group_col2 provided, overall analysis performed. group_col2 string specifying second grouping column. Default NULL. multilevel_col string specifying column name identifies repeated measurements (e.g., patient sample IDs). provided, multilevel analysis performed. Default NULL. batch_col string specifying column identifies batch study sample. ind_names TRUE, row names first (second) data matrix used names. Default FALSE. character vector provided, values used names. 'pch' set overwrite names shapes. See ?mixOmics::plotIndiv details. colors vector colors groups treatments. NULL, random palette (using rainbow) generated based number groups. output_file Optional string specifying name file created.  NULL (default), plots drawn current graphics device. Ensure file extension matches desired format (e.g., ".pdf" PDF output ".png" PNG output .tiff TIFF output). ellipse Logical. Whether draw 95\ figures. Default FALSE. bg Logical. Whether draw prediction background figures. Default FALSE. conf_mat Logical. Whether print confusion matrix classifications. Default FALSE. var_num Numeric. number variables used PLS-DA model. cv_opt Character. Option cross-validation method: either "loocv" "Mfold". Default NULL. fold_num Numeric. number folds use cv_opt "Mfold". Default 5. scale Character string specifying transformation apply numeric predictor columns prior model fitting.  Options "none", "log2", "log10", "zscore", "custom".  "custom" selected user defined function must supplied via custom_fn.  Defaults "none". custom_fn custom transformation function used scale = "custom".  Ignored otherwise.  take numeric vector return numeric vector length. tune Logical.  TRUE, performs tuning ncomp keepX via cross‑validation.  Default FALSE. tune_folds Integer.  Number folds cross‑validation tuning.  Default 5. comp_num Numeric. number components calculate sPLS-DA model. Default 2. pch_values vector integers specifying plotting characters (pch values) used plots. style Character. set "3D" "3d" comp_num equals 3, 3D plot generated using plot3D package. Default NULL. roc Logical. Whether compute plot ROC curve model. Default FALSE. verbose logical value indicating whether print additional informational output console. TRUE, function display progress messages, intermediate results FALSE (default), runs quietly. seed integer specifying seed reproducibility (default 123).

title: Two Sample T-test Comparisons.  — cyt_ttest
text: function performs pairwise comparisons two groups combination categorical predictor (exactly two levels) continuous outcome variable. first converts character variables data factors , specified, applies log2 transformation continuous variables. Depending value scale, function conducts either two-sample t-test (scale = "log2") Mann-Whitney U test (scale NULL). resulting p-values printed returned.

title: Two Sample T-test Comparisons.  — cyt_ttest
code: cyt_ttest(data, scale = NULL, verbose = TRUE, format_output = FALSE)

title: Two Sample T-test Comparisons.  — cyt_ttest

Options NULL (default) "log2". scale = "log2", log2 transformation applied two-sample t-test used; scale NULL, Mann-Whitney U test performed. verbose logical indicating whether print p-values statistical tests. Default TRUE. format_output Logical. TRUE, returns results tidy data frame. Default FALSE.

title: Pairwise Univariate Tests Between Two Groups — cyt_univariate
text: data data frame matrix containing categorical numeric variables. scale character specifying transformation apply numeric variables prior testing.  Choices NULL (transformation), "log2", "log10", "zscore", "custom".  set "custom", supply function via custom_fn. method Character specifying test perform.  Use "auto" (default) select t‑test Wilcoxon based Shapiro–Wilk normality tests outcome; "ttest" always use Student’s t‑test; "wilcox" always use Wilcoxon rank–sum test. verbose Logical indicating whether return results. Provided backward compatibility effect printing. format_output Logical.  TRUE, returns results tidy data frame; FALSE (default), returns list test objects similar original function. custom_fn function apply scale = "custom". p_adjust_method Character NULL. Method passed p.adjust() correcting p-values across comparisons (e.g., "BH" Benjamini-Hochberg). NULL (default) adjustment performed.

title: Pairwise Univariate Tests Between Two Groups — cyt_univariate

title: Univariate Tests for Multi‑Level Categorical Predictors — cyt_univariate_multi
text: cyt_univariate_multiprovides univariate statistical testing categorical predictors two levels.  categorical predictor numeric outcome pair, global test performed, followed pairwise comparisons global test significant.  Users may choose two methods, classical ANOVA Tukey’s Honest Significant Difference (HSD) non‑parametric Kruskal–Wallis test followed pairwise Wilcoxon rank–sum tests.  return format can either list adjusted p‑values outcome–predictor pair , format_output = TRUE, tidy data frame summarizing pairwise comparisons.

NULL, factor character columns data used. cont_vars Optional character vector numeric outcome variable names.  NULL, numeric columns data used. p_adjust_method Character string specifying method p‑value adjustment across pairwise comparisons.  Passed p.adjust.  Default "BH". format_output Logical.  TRUE, returns tidy data frame; otherwise (default) returns list numeric vectors keyed "Outcome_Categorical".  numeric vector contains adjusted p‑values pairwise comparisons.

title: Volcano plot — cyt_volc

Additionally, choice t‑tests Wilcoxon rank‑sum tests adjusting p‑values multiple comparisons.

what: Run XGBoost Classification on Cytokine Data. — cyt_xgb

code: cyt_xgb(   data,   group_col,   train_fraction = 0.7,   nrounds = 500,   max_depth = 6,   learning_rate = 0.1,   nfold = 5,   cv = FALSE,   objective = "multi:softprob",   early_stopping_rounds = NULL,   eval_metric = "mlogloss",   min_split_loss = 0,   colsample_bytree = 1,   subsample = 1,   min_child_weight = 1,   top_n_features = 10,   verbose = 0,   plot_roc = FALSE,   print_results = FALSE,   seed = 123,   scale = c("none", "log2", "log10", "zscore", "custom"),   custom_fn = NULL )

title: Run XGBoost Classification on Cytokine Data. — cyt_xgb
text: data data frame containing numeric predictor variables one grouping column.  Non-numeric predictor columns coerced numeric possible. group_col Character string naming column contains class labels (target variable).  Required. train_fraction Numeric 0 1 specifying proportion samples used model training.  remainder reserved testing.  Default 0.7. nrounds Integer specifying number boosting rounds. Default 500. max_depth Integer specifying maximum depth tree. Default 6. learning_rate Numeric specifying learning rate.  Default 0.1. nfold Integer specifying number folds cross-validation cv = TRUE.  Default 5. cv Logical indicating whether perform cross-validation using xgb.cv.  Default FALSE. objective Character string specifying objective function.  multi-class classification use "multi:softprob"; binary classification use "binary:logistic".  Default "multi:softprob". early_stopping_rounds Integer specifying number rounds without improvement trigger early stopping.  Default NULL (early stopping). eval_metric Character specifying evaluation metric used training.  Default "mlogloss". min_split_loss Numeric specifying minimum loss reduction required make partition.  Default 0. colsample_bytree Numeric specifying subsample ratio columns constructing tree.  Default 1. subsample Numeric specifying subsample ratio training instances.  Default 1. min_child_weight Numeric specifying minimum sum instance weight needed child.  Default 1. top_n_features Integer specifying number top features display importance plot.  Default 10. verbose Integer (0, 1 2) controlling verbosity xgb.train.  Default 0.  Larger values print information. plot_roc Logical indicating whether plot ROC curve compute AUC binary classification.  Default FALSE. print_results Logical.  TRUE, prints confusion matrix, top features cross-validation metrics console.  Default FALSE. seed Optional integer seed reproducibility.  Default 123. scale Character string specifying transformation apply numeric predictors prior model fitting.  Possible values "none", "log2", "log10", "zscore" "custom".  set "custom" user defined function must supplied via custom_fn.  Defaults "none". custom_fn custom transformation function used scale = "custom".  Ignored otherwise.  take numeric vector return numeric vector length.

title: Run XGBoost Classification on Cytokine Data. — cyt_xgb
text: invisible list elements: model (trained xgboost object), confusion_matrix (test set confusion matrix), importance (variable importance matrix), class_mapping (mapping class names numeric labels), cv_results (cross-validation results cv=TRUE), importance_plot (ggplot2 object top feature importance), roc_plot (ROC curve binary classification plot_roc=TRUE).  plots printed automatically.

title: Run XGBoost Classification on Cytokine Data. — cyt_xgb
code: data_df0 <- ExampleData1 data_df <- data.frame(data_df0[, 1:3], log2(data_df0[, -c(1:3)])) data_df <- data_df[, -c(2:3)] data_df <- dplyr::filter(data_df, Group != "ND") cyt_xgb(  data = data_df,  group_col = "Group",  nrounds = 250,  max_depth = 4,  min_split_loss = 0,  learning_rate = 0.05,  nfold = 5,  cv = FALSE,  objective = "multi:softprob",  eval_metric = "auc",  plot_roc = TRUE,  print_results = FALSE)

title: CytoProfile (development version)
text: New functions ‘cyt_univariate’ t-test wilcoxon rank sum test ‘cyt_univariate_multi’ ANOVA Kruskal-Wallis test added conduct univariate statistical analysis multiple groups. Changed ‘cyt_bp’ adapt grouping similar ‘cyt_bp2’ longer need separate functions New function ‘cyt_violin’ creating violin plots statistical comparisons groups. Two new helper functions apply different types transformations adjust p-values. Added options scale/transformations functions require added p-value adjustment options needed.

title: CytoProfile 0.2.3
text: CRAN release: 2025-12-06

title: CytoProfile 0.2.3
text: Make ‘cyt_xgb’ compatible upcoming XGBoost R package changes (parameter renames, changes predict() output). Fix ROC/AUC computation confusion matrix computation XGBoost models. Deprecate arguments ‘eta’ ‘gamma’ cyt_xgb() favor ‘learning_rate’ ‘min_split_loss’ using lifecycle package.

title: CytoProfile 0.2.2

title: CytoProfile 0.2.2
text: ‘cyt_mint_splsda’, new function conducting multivariate integrative analysis using sparse partial least squares discriminant analysis (sPLS-DA) multiple datasets, added. ‘cyt_splsda’ now new arguments: ‘batch_col’ specify batch column batch correction sPLS-DA analysis using Z-score method. ‘multilevel_col’ specify multilevel column multilevel analysis sPLS-DA. ‘ind_names’ specify custom individual names samples plots. Added new “ExampleData5” dataset “ExampleData1” batch column demonstration ‘batch_col’ argument ‘cyt_mint_splsda’. ‘cyt_heatmap’ now uses pheatmap plotting, provides proper legend along additional scaling options.
